children: Acquired chronic pure red cell aplasia is characterized by the absence or a marked decrease of erythrocyte production with normal leukocyte and platelet counts. The cause is predominately T-cell autoimmunity (pregnancy, thymoma, malignancy) or direct toxicity to erythrocyte precursors (viral infection, drug toxicity).
Bone marrow shows profound erythroid hypoplasia.
The basic evaluation is similar to that for pancytopenia but includes CT of the chest to rule out thymoma.
Patients with pure red cell aplasia are treated with:
transfusion support and immunosuppressive drugs (prednisone, cyclosporine, antithymocyte globulin)
